User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9a1) Gecko/20060327 Firefox/1.6a1
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9a1) Gecko/20060327 Firefox/1.6a1

Memory use grows substantially with time, when viewing articles in www.globes.co.il - a major Israeli financial site.

Seems to me that this behavior/bug is at least since the FireFox 1.5 release. I have 512MB of memory which is adequate at the start, but due to the memory growth, it is all exhausted, and starts swapping to disk, making FireFox hang for a long time.

It might be a memory leak, I don't know how to check it.


Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Go to http://www.globes.co.il .(If it asks you what language, I have chosen Hebrew, but I believe that the bug will show also in the english version, since it seems to me that it is related to the heavy graphics)
2. open many articles in multiple tabs, about 20 (to make the memory growth be more rapid)
3. Note the memory use as reported by task manager after all pages finished loading
4. leave it open for several hours to a day.
5. Note again the memory use, this time it will be several 100MBs higher than before.


Actual Results:  
substantial memory use growth as reported by task manager

Expected Results:  
Have more or less the same memory use as after loading initially all the tabs/pages.

High memory usage does not necessarily indicate a leak. Knowing which actions specifically leak, rather than general usage overtime is far more helpful.

Please see the following information on filing memory leak bugs and file a new
one if you're able to find a leak using the tools described:

comments.raw_text:
I don't understand why it was marked as invalid, please reconsider:
I didn't say it is a memory leak.
The high growth in memory usage over time is the bug , regardless if it is a leak or not.
I didn't write that because of the high memory usage, it is a memory leak. I said it MAY BE a memory leak. I know that it doesn't necessarily have to be a leak.

You wrote: "Knowing which actions specifically leak, rather than general usage overtime is far more helpful."

I didn't give any specific actions to do because there aren't any. You just have to leave it the browser open with 20 tabs not doing anything, and the memory use will grow (regardless if it is a leak or not)

Last, In principal David Baron's leak detection tool detects only specific types of leaks, not all leaks, so even if a leak cannot be detected with this tool (didn't try yet due to time constraints) it doesn't mean there is no leak, and it should still be marked as a valid bug report and not made INVALID, at least until the simple steps to reproduce were tried and failed.

Please change the status from INVALID

comments.text: I've had ~15 or so tabs open to various globes.co.il articles for over 18 hours now in build 20060403 and have noticed nothing abnormal. The only possible problem  I can see would be the front page's meta refresh (covered by bug 261920). There are literally dozens of other bugs that could apply to what globes.co.il is using but without knowing which issue specifically is causing the high usage you're seeing, this bug isn't particularly helpful in getting something fixed. If you're able to find a specific element in the site's content that creates an issue, please produce a reduced testcase and file another bug.

comments.raw_text:
Thanks for the information.
Please let me know whether for the ~15 tabs of articles you used the Hebrew or English version of the site www.globes.co.il  ?

I have investigated some more after your response that you don't see the growing memory behavior.
The possibilities I ruled out were:
1. That I use the SessionSaver Extension and it causes the problem
2. That it is due to the front page refresh meta tag. 

I disabled the SessionSaver extension and rerun the test, closing the front page immediately after opening all the tabs. The memory still grows substantially.

When I ran the test with the English version of the site, I have a preliminary result (until now after 2 hours, I had to stop it) that the memory seemingly DOES NOT grow substantially, but I need to do a more thorough test with more time.
Therefore it is possible that the bug appears only with the Hebrew version, and I need to know what language version of the site you used.
